Mr. Harold Hill
October $, 1962
Mr. Raymond Hurlbert
General Manager
Alabama Educational Television Commission
2151 Highland Avenue
Birmingham 5, Alabama
Dear Raymond;
In response to your letter of October 3 concerning my serving as
a consultant to the radio section of the RAEB Region II Conference
next March, I am sure you know that I am more than pleased to make
any contribution I can to this or any other section of the meeting.
I trust you or Len will let me know more specifically what I may
be expected to do as you develop the plans in greater detail.
May I raise a question concerning scheduling of the radio sessions
prior to the TV sessions. If I am not mistaken, this same plan
has fallen through two or three times in the past. In many cases
the radio people are traveling with the TV people and the group as
a whole could not arrive until the actual kick off of the entire
conference. I have not made an acourate count of the number of
active and associate members in Region II who are involved pri¬
marily in radio as opposed to TV, but I think a careful check
might show that the numbers are about equal. In any event, there
is a sizable membership interested in radio. My impression of the
last three or four regional meetings is that, for one reason or
another, comparatively little time has been devoted to radio; the
big emphasis being on TV.
I do not Intend this comment as a criticism of what has been done
and I may be entirely inaccurate; but I strongly urge that radio
be given more emphasis at the next meeting, even to the extent of
devoting some of the major sessions to radio. My reasons for this
suggestion are two fold. In the first place we have a significant
number of radio-involved people in Region II and their interests
and problems should be served in these meetings. Secondly, educa¬
tional radio is at a precarious point nationally. Many institu¬
tions, Including my own, are now questioning the value of contin¬
uing the radio station operation as television becomes increasingly
dynamic. I am told by the NAEB national office that a wave of
negativism toward educational radio Is sweeping the country and
there is much concern that we will see the demise of a number or
educational radio stations before the trend turns. This is es¬
pecially true in the case of PM stations.
